div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: England and Japan.
div.p: Admiral Noel, with his squadron of cruisers, has seen Kobe, the port that ranks second only to Yokohama in importance and claims in respect of commerce with foreign countries even to have outstripped its northern rival. Kobe dates its existence as a place of resi- dence for Europeans from 1868, but Yoko- hama took shape as a foreign settlement nine years earlier than that. From Kobe the British Admiral steamed to Yokohama on Saturday morning, and entered the Gulf of Tokio, at the head of which lies the Japanese capital, on Thursday at daylight. His visit this autumn to those waters is memorable by reason of the exceptional conditions under which it is being paid, and the Japanese Navy Department has resolved that the re- ception of the British vessels shall be indi- cative of the strong friendship which now indubitably exists between the allied peoples. At the moment that he entered the gulf Admiral Noel was within a few miles of Uraga, the spot where Commodore Perry made his historic attempt in 1858 to open up communication between the then se- cluded Japanese nation and the outside world. Perry's success came in the following year, when on calling at Uraga to receive the promised reply from the Japanese Government to President Fillmore's courteous communica- ion he was hospitably entertained ashore, and he subsequently steamed with his four vessels into the gulf until he was off Shinagawa, the southern suburb of Tokio. Little could it have been imagined that half a century later a Japanese fleet of something like 200 warships of all sizes would lie just within the bay, many of them fresh from a campaign against one of the greatest Powers of the Occident, awaiting the arrival of a squadron flying the flag of a Western ally. Yet these figures represent approximately the naval strength which Japan exhibited off Yokosuka, when the Emperor journeyed thither from Tokio, 30 miles distant, to review his victorious fleet. Admiral Togo's wonderful success at Tau-shima Straits relieved the mind of his countrymen of a terrible burden of anxiety, and his prowess has been fittingly acknowledged on all sides, but the forthcoming review by the Emperor will set the seal of the Sovereign's approval on the achievements of the Navy in general, and the day will be regarded as one to be remembered in Japan for all time. Yokusuka itself has associations for Englishmen which ought to be better known and appre- ciated, for not only was it the first naval depot to be constructed by our allies, but it is the burial place of Will Adams, the Ro- therhithe shipwright who found himself strand- ed in Japan at the end of the sixteenth cen- tury, and quickly made himself so useful to the reigning Shogun, the founder of the Tokugawa line, as to be retained perma- nently in the country's service. Adams was the first to hold the appointment, it may be said, of Chief Constructor of the Japanese Navy, and his memory is cherished in Tokio to this day, where there is a street- An-Jin-Cho- named after him. An-jin, it should be un- derstood, means "pilot," and it was as a pilot on board a Dutch vessel that Adams reached Japan in the first place. His grave is on a hill overlooking Yokosuka, the tiny fishing village which has grown into a great naval station, all within thirty-five years, and will form this week the centre of an unparalleled demonstration of maritime pro- gress and rapidly-acquired efficiency.

The British squadron has been welcomed in truly regal fashion, and all classes have shown how thoroughly they enter into the meaning, and spirit of the Anglo-Japanese Alliance. It is the custom throughout Japan to display on annual festival days at windows and doorways the national flag of a red ball on a white ground, and in a village street so decorated the effect is usually very pretty. On the present occasion the Japanese and British flags have flown together and Admiral Noel's officers and men have been everywhere enthusiastically entertained, apart from the more formal banqueting that is to take place in their honor in the capital. The Maple Club, at which the British officers met the Cabinet Ministers and representative officers of the Japanese Army and Navy, had its origin in very humble begin- nings in the early Seventies, when a few Japan- ese and European residents foregathered for sociable converse and recreation not far from the spot where stands the commodious club- house of to-day. The roll of membership is now a long one, for the members are to be courted by the thousand, and there will be no mistak- ing the character of the reception which will be accorded the British guests when they reach the Maple Club's hospitable doors. It is a happy coincidence that the ratification of the Peace Treaty between Japan and Russia will occur simultaneously with the visit of the British Squadron and the grand naval review in the Tokio Gulf, for a settled conviction has now taken possession of the Japanese mind that the durable peace which was longed for has become assured to the nation, by means of its alliances with Great Britain.

In an interview with a representative of the “Echo de Parin” M Delcasse dis laimed any connection with the revelations published by the “Matin". When asked if the revelations are imaginary, he smiled and begged the inter- viewer not to ask him any more questions. (Reuter)

Paris, October 12. M. Juares in an article of the "Humanite” declares that he knows that immediately after the Emperor William's visit to Tangier M. Delcasse informed the Cabinet that Great Britain had offered to come to the assistance of France in the event of an armed conflict. Great Britain was prepared even by a written treaty to engage to mobilise the fleet, and to land 10O,OOO men in Germany. The only detail of which M. Juares is ignorant is that of Schleswig-Holstein. (Reuter)

Berlin, October 12. The inspired German press treats the reve- lations of the “Matin” as being most serious, and displays great irritation at the hostile disposition imputed to Great Britain. It is reported that the matter has formed a subject for informal diplomatic discussion between Great Britain and Germany. (Reuter)

Paris, October 12 In a letter to the Figaro," M.Dolcasse declares that he had nothing to do with the articles published by the "Matin” on the subject of the support promised to France by England against Germany. (Havas)
Yokohama, October 12. The British squadron has been enthsias- tically received. Admiral Noel will go to Tokio this morning. (Reuter)
Yokohama, October 20. An enthusiastic welcome was given to the British squadron. (Havas)

Tokio, October 12. Admiral Noel and his staff with a thousand men arrived at Tokio this morning and were received in the most enthusiastic manner. The whole city was decked out with flags as it was after the most important victories. The day was observed as a general holiday. The Cabinet Ministers, the Marquis of Ito, and other high naval and military officers met them at the station, and Admiral Noel drove in an imperial carriage through cheering crowds to Hibiya Park, where the Mayor entertained the visitors at luncheon, and athletic and other displays. (Reuter)

Cape Town, October 12. A despatch received by the Government Upington states that the Hottentot Chief Marengo has captured a German camp at Jerusalem after severe fighting, in which the Germans lost a lieutenant and six men killed and eight wounded. Others were captured, disarmed and released. The Hottentots had no losses, and they captured all the stores. They told those who had been taken prisoners that they are ready to take the offensive, and will fight to the bitter end.
As Marengo is approaching Klipplaats the garrison has burned the stores and retired. (Reuter)
London, October 12. It is not likely that the Bank rate will be raised today, but it is feared that a rise is inevitable later on, if the drain to America, Egypt, and Argentina should continue. (R.)

London, October 12. The New Zealand team is defeating every English team with the utmost ease, partly on account of the excellence of individuals and partly on account of the new distribution in the field. They have scored until now 310 points against 7, in 8 matches. (Reuter)

Stray and ownerless Dogs found in the Abdin district of Cairo during tomorrow night and at dawn of the 15th inst. will be poisoned by the police.
Suez Canal —The number of vessels enter- ing snd passing through the Canal from the 6th to the 9th inst. was no less than 87, the amount received in dues being fr. 2,875,340,12.

Army Arabic Examination.- Lieutenant- Colonel C.G. Markham, 1st Battalion King’s Royal Rifle Corps, and Staff Sergeant H. N. Hartnoll, Royal Engineers, qualified at the Army Arabic examination held on the 11th ult.

The Brindisi Mail will be made up at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday. Registered letters must be handed in by 2 10 p.m. and insured articles and money orders at midday. Parcels must be handed in by 6 o’clock on Saturday evening.

Murber at Tineh. A fellsh of Tineh Tahta Markaz, while walking along the road was shot by a man who had lain in ambush for him, and fired at point blank range. The murderer, who has been arrested, appears to have been under the impression that his son had been killed by the victim.

Turkish Telegraphs.—The Ottoman Go- vernment is making investigations with a view to the construction of a new telegraphic line to Egypt via Syria, and another new line between Beyrout and Europe. The latter cable will also be joined with the E Arish line via Beyrout and with the cable laid direct between Constantinople and Berlin.

Old Bourse Palace Bar —The well known Austrian orchestra, composed entirely of mem bers of the Hackmeyer family will play every night at the well known Old Bourse Palace Bar belonging to Messrs Walkerand Meimarach, commencing at 8 p.m. The orchestra is well known to our Alexandria readers and thoroughly well-trained and competent.

Pro Calabria — A performance in aid of the victims of the Calabrian Earthquake will be given at the Eden theatre to-morrow night. La Tombola, a farce, will be given by the La Margherita Dramatic Society and a good musical programme will be rendered the Arme- nian band having kindly volunteered to give its services to the case of charity.

The Egyptian Directory. — Messrs. Rizzo and Co. inform the public that the next annual edition of their directory will appear towards the end of December. They there- fore beg all persons, win wish to. change their addresses or make any other corrections to be good enough to communicate them at once to Messrs. Rizzo & Co's offices; Mercioca Buildings, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo.

The New Eldorado Café. – A new café Was opened yesterday in connection with the Alhambra theatre by M. Conegliano. The Café is in a large building admirably fitted up and to judge from yesterday’s experience can boast of an excellent service. A Tzgare orchestra will perform daily from 5 to 8 p.m. and from 9 p.m. to 1.30 a.m., and there are also both English and French billiard tables for those who enjoy that game, whilst chess, draughts, dominoes, etc. are also provided.

Cab-Drivers in Egypt.- “El Lewa” states than an edict was recently issued by the Ministry of the Interior by which all cab- drivers who are not possessed of the sight of both eyes were forbidden to continue in that business. Several of these, who foresaw the difficulty of earning their daily bread by other means, took action against H.E. Mustafa Pasha Fahmi, president of the Council of Ministers, at the Court of Szida Zenab. In their action they demanded that either the edict should be repealed or that all their former colleagues in business, who are afflicted with the same trouble, should have their licenses taken away. The Muhzir of the Court has since intimated to his Excel- lency that the demand of the plaintiffs must be acceded to, failing which he will be pro- ceded against in a higher court.

Horrible Murder.- A fellah of Tawabieh, Desneh Markaz, recently accured his wife of stealing his two guns and giving them to one of her relatives. Though he does not seem to have made his accusation good, he resolved to kill her during her sleep and struck her re- peatedly on the head with a naboot. Believing that he had disposed of her he then went to the Omdeh and informed him that thieves bad broken into his house. The Omdeh went to the house at once and found that the woman had partially recovered from the stunning effect of blows. He asked her whether she knew the naname of the thief. “It was my husband” was her reply. The Omdeh instantly left the house to inform the proper authorities and the husband, fearing further disclosures, cut the unfortunate woman’s tongue out. The victim of this appalling act of savagery has since succumbed to her injuries. The husband has been imprisoned and will, we hope, receive the sentence which he deserves.

div.head: COLLISION AT KAFR ZAYAT. MAILS DELAYED THREE HOURS.
div.p: A collision occurred here shortly before mid- night, when a pilot engine crashed into a goods train coming from Alexandria made up of trucks principally laden with vegetables. The pilot engine was shunting, and whilst crossing the connection between the up and down lines met the up goods train which was running into the station. Coming into collision with one of the trucks, the momentum of the engine carried it over the goods train, and two trucks were badly broken, while six others were derailed and lay across both lines.

The sleeping car trains which were due to meet at Kafr el Zayat at 2.50 a.m. both found the lines completely blocked and the passen- gers were transferred from one train to the other, each of which returned to the station from which it had started. At the time of wiring both lines are still blocked, the cranes for removing the derailed trucks only having arrived an hour ago, but it is expected that the traffic will be able to be resumed without interruption by noon. Two of the fireman of the pilot engine were slightly injured, but no other accidents to persons are recorded. The accident is said to be the fault of the driver of the pilot engine but no definite conclusion has been arrived at.

The sleeping-car train which left Alexandria At 11:30 last night returned this morning about 9 o’clock with the passengers who had taken the corresponding train from Cairo and it was not until nearly 11 a.m. that the mails were delivered. We hear that one of the lines at Kafr el Zayat was cleared by 10 a.m. and that both early morning expresses have get past the scene of the accident. The dining-car expresses left their respective stations up to time, and it is not anticipated that they will suffer any delay.

Kafr el Zayat station must have been an Exciting spot in which to pass last night, for The collision was not the only event that dis- turbed its occupants. A fire broke out among a number of cotton bales, and serious damage would have been caused, had it not been for the energetic measures of the railway officials, who finally extinguished the flames.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: This morning H.H. the Khedive attended prayers at the Mosque of Sidi Bishr, Ramleh, and afterward visited the fair held in honor of the Moslem Saint. This afternoon his Highness will attend the regatta at the Khe- divial Yacht Club, and to-night he will attend the religious service at the Mosque of Sidi Abou el Abbas on the occasion of the Nus- Shaaban feast.

div.head: THE SHERIF OF MECCA.
div.p: The prophecy which appeared in the Egyp- tian Press some two months ago, that Abd-ul- llsh Pasha would certainly succeed the late Aun-Er-Rafik Pasha as Sherif of Mecca is now unlikely to be fulfilled. The Vali of the Hedjaz appears to have protested against Abd-ul-IIah’s appointment to the "Mabein” on the ground of his religious influence among the more austere moslems of the vilayet. The foot that the late Sherif of Mecca had received letters from the Imam Yahya Ibn Hamid el-Din of the Yemen, naturally made the Turkish Go- vernment very nervous of appointing any Arab to the Sherifat whose personal influence might possibly be thrown into the balance against the Ottoman power, and Ali Pasha, Abd-ul-IIah’s cousin will almost certainly succeed the late Sherif Auner Rafik.

div.head: GABBARI TIMBER QUAYS
div.p: Tenders for the construction of the new timber quats at Gabbari were called for in the Journal Official of the 15th July, to be opened On the 16th inst. The Ports and Lights Ad- ministration received twenty-seven applica- tions for the “cashiers des charges” but only five offers were actually received, viz, those of Sir John Aird, Messrs. Bencini and Quistas, and Messrs. Mazzar and Gerakis. We under- stand that Messrs. Almagia are in far the best position among all the competiting firms to make a moderate tender since they are in possession of all the plant etc. necessary for the work, and have the great advantage of local experience and of having all their machinery and plant on the spot.

div.p: The following are the programmes of music To be played by the Brachale orchestra at 5 o’clock this evening and to-morrow respect- ively :-

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Moeris sailed from Malia Yesterday afternoon and is due at Alexandria on Monday nex with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liner Menes sailed from Malta Yesterday morning, homeward bound.

div.head: CANAL NEWS.
div.p: Port Said, Thursday.

The last batch of vessels from Suez arrived here this morning and again, every berth in the harbour is occupied. Great difficulty was experienccd in mooring these vessels, owing to the heavy sea which was running at the time. I hear from a reliable source that after to-day vessels will be able to enter the canal any time during the day. No ships have yet been allowed to pass kilometre 18.4 after sunset, and from what I hear they will not be allowed to do so this week.
The S.S. Dalmatia, which arrived here this morning from Caloutta bound to Loudon, was found to have an infectious case on board, and was kept in compulsory quarantine.

div.head: THE MATARIEH CANAL
div.p: The Matarieh Canal service is an accom- plisbed fact, for I have met several people who have made short voyages in the company’s small vessels, of which everyone speaks most highly. The small passenger boats appa- rently quite come up to expectations, and the cargo service is likely to be at work regularly in a few weeks.

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: The prospects of our town team are distinct- ly rosy. Most of last year's players are avail- ble,and there are also several newcomers who will t lay for Port Said, and as some of these are said to be especially good players, the old members will have to play up if they wish to keep their places. The season does not open till November, when they will encounter their local rivals the Suez E.T.C. Club. The latter team are also looking forward to an im- proved condition of things, and they are not without hope that the boot will be on the other leg, and that Captain Wallis and his men will on that occasion have to take a second place. —But we shall see.

div.head: THE SAY REFINERY
div.p: (From our London Correspondent).
(By Telegraph).
London, Thursday.

At the extraordinary shareholders’ meeting of the Say Refinery held yesterday a resolution for the reorganisation of the company was adopt- ed, but it was decided to postpone the discus- sion upon M. Cronier's management until the general meeting which will be held in Nov- ember.

div.head: PORT OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: We understand that the authorities are making considerable progress with the work of the new quay extensions, and that they have several dredgers at work at the present time which have been hired from the British Admiralty and other sources.

We also understand that they have placed an order with the British Engineering Co., of Egypt, Ltd., for a dredger capable of dredging 1030 tons per hour, two 600 ton hopper barges, and a new tug, all of which have to be delivered at Alexandria by June 30 next year.
The above will be built on the Clyde by Mssrs. William Simons and Co. Ltd. The contract price is close on £50,000.

div.head: THE POPULATION OF OUR CITIES
div.p: According to the official tables just publish- ed the native population of Cairo and its sub- urbs was estimated on the 1st July last at 615,132. As no returns are furnished by the Consulates regarding the number of their sub- jects no exact estimate can be made of the foreign population. The census of June 1897, gave this at 35,219, but this figure must have been considerably augmented since then and the inhabitants of European nationality must number quite 50,000.
The same tables give the number of the native population of Alexandria on the above date as 316,632 and the European 46,118. Hera again the latter figures are those of the last census.

div.head: VITALITY STATISTICS.
div.p: From the latest returns of the Statistical Department in Cairo, we find that the total number of births in that city during the week ending 30th ultimo was 458, including 6 of foreign parentage ; this is at the rate of 39.9 per thousand of the estimated population. The deaths for the same week numbers 379, includ- ing 12 of European nationality; this being at the rate of 31.0 per thousand for the native and 17.7 for the foreign portion of the inhabitants. During the corresponding period of last year the total of deaths was 357 and the ratio 29.8 and 19.2 respectively.

At Alexandria the births for the week under review were 306, which included 19 children of European parentage, the rate per thousand of the total population being 47.1. The deaths numbered 345, of which 18 were of foreign nationality. The rate was 32.4 for the native and 20.3 per thousand for the European portion of the inhabitants. During the corresponding period of last year the numbers were 236 and 22 respectively and the ratio 39.6 and 24.8 per thousand.

div.head: THE OMODHOS SHOW.
div.p: The Annual Fair and Horse Show was held At Omodhos, near Troodos, on the 27th ult. The fair, which is primarily of a religious character, is one of the most important, and villagers to the number of several thousands annually flock to it to worship at the little church, where a piece of the true cross and rope are exhibited. The fair is one of conside- rable interest to the ordinary European tourist, as the peasants are for the most part seen in all their finery and a considerable trade in the products peculiar to the Island may be seen in progress. Thither also the dealers in "anticas" find their way, and among the trash which they there try to dispose of may often be discovered by the “knowing’’ ones some pretty and genuine specimens of native silver and other work. The Horse Show is a development of recent years, and is organised under the aus- pices of the Committee for the Improvement of Cyprus Stock. There had been no show for two years, but the entries appeared up to the former average, and it is hoped that every year greater interest will be evinced by native owners of horses and donkeys. An excellent lunch and tea were kindly provided by three ladies, wives of English officials, to which about 60 guests sat down. His Excellency the High Commissioner and Lady King Harman, with their daughter and Mr. Lewis Biddulph, were present, who, when the proceedings termina- ted, started off for a three days’ tour in the district. Colonel Griffiths, Army Veterinary surgeon from Cairo, was among the judges.

div.head: PERSONAL
div.p: Captain Kennedy, who as A.D.C. to General Bullock, came to Cyprus a few weeks back, succumbed shortly after his arrival on Trodos to enteric fever, which he doubtless contract- ed before leaving Egypt. He is now said to be progressing favorably. Captain Lear- month, the new Chief Commandant of Po- lice crossed over to Port Said some three weeks ago in order to meet his wife and children. Owing to the illness of one of the latter has has been detained at that port. Lieut. Creichton and Mr. Deedes (King's Royal Rifles) arrived in Cyprus by last mail, and joined the detachment in camp at Troo- dos. Mr. A. Graunum, Local Auditor, left for England last week on leave of absence.

div.head: ENTERTAINMENT AT TROODOS.
div.p: Advantage was taken of the presence on Trodos of several newcomers, who had ar- rived for the Omodhos Show, to give a Dramatic Performance and Variety Enterain- ment in the Soldiers' Recreation Room, on the 27th ultimo. Several ladies and gentle- men assisted in the theatricals, and the “Tommies" contributed the variety entertain- ment between the two plays. Both pieces were excellently acted, and were highly appre- ciated by a numerous audience. The Regiment must also be congratulated upon the conspicuous musical talent of several of the men. As a wind-up to a festive week, a capital dance was given on the 29th by the Officers of the regiment in the newly built hotel, which was kept up with mnch spirit to a late hour.
Mansfield Pasha, Commandant of Police at Cairo, has been granted an extension of leave To the 5th November.
Our popular confrere M.R. Canivet return- ed to Alexandria from Europe yesterday.
Major Frank Douglas Pennant, King’s Royal Rifle Corps, has retired from the service.
Mr. Bauer, proprietor of the Hotel Bristol and manager of the new National Hotel at Cairo, is returning on Sunday from Europe by The Rubattino steamer.
The Marriage of Mr. E. Kudsi, the popular representative of “Al Mokattam” and “Al Muktatah,” to Miss Aneisa Jureidini will take place on the 22nd inst.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. R. Vaughan Wild, Mr. K. Coes, General Adams, Colonel Stewart, Mrs. Craster. Mr. F. Murrell Wright Mr.s A. E. Bruklmann, Mr. Emeliolas, Mr. A. E. Branch, Cooksbank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank, Mrs. And Miss A.M. Boiley, Mr. and Mrs. Archer, Mr. J.J. Kirkness, Mrs. Seelay and infant, Mr. G. Pollock, Mr. M.M. Shaamer, Mr. J.R. Campbell, Mrs. O.H. Or- merod, Mr. W. Walsh, Mr. W.S. Sevasly, Mr. Aug. Van Millingen, Mr. Staklmann, Mr. D. A.M. Broned, Mr. E.N. Bratt, Mrs. Bratt, Miss Tomlin, Miss Craven, Mr. Dudgeon, Mr. And Mrs. T. Bajocchi, Mr. J. Watson, Mr. W. J. Butler, Mr. H.M. Anthony, Mr. and Mrs. A. C. Martin, Mr. J. Maix, Mr. A. Stamm, Capt. and Mrs. Gaush, Mr. V.A. Royle. Mr. E Greedy, Dr. and Mrs. Betts, Capt. W.L. Betts.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh: Mr. and Mrs. Macpherson Grant, Mr. Georges Romanes, Mr. W.N. Perkins, Mr. and Mrs. I. Daniel Miss C. Hill, Mr. and Mrs. T. Rizordimos, Mr. Emile Camel, Mme A. Cadross. Miss Raubia Camel Bey, Dr. and Mrs. Mackenzie and family, Mr. W. L. Balley, Mr. and Mrs. H. Spratt, Mr. G. Metral, Miss L. Cox, Miss A. Irvins.

div.head: Le Proces Des Princes
div.p: Voici le texte de l’ordonnance rendue hier Par M. Tuck dans l’affaire Heritiers Ismail- Daira Sanieh:
Nous president,
Vu le recours en refere introduit suivant exploit en date du 9 octobre 1905:
Attendu que la Daira Sanieh de S.A. le Khedive a demande a intervenir dans l'ins- tance.
Attendu que l'acte d'assignation du 10 sout 1905, signifie a la requete des heritiers de feu S.A. le Khedive Ismail pacha, contient :

1. Defense su Credit Foncier d'avoir a ver- ser soit a la Daira Sanieh Co. Ltd, soit a la Daira Sanieh de S.A. le Khedive, soit au Gouvernement Egyptien, le surplus qui pour- rait resulter apres la liquidation et dont le Credit Foncier resulterait debiteur.

2. Defense a la Daira Sanieh Co. Ltd. d'a- voir a verser soit a la Daira Sanieh de S.A le Khedive, soit au Gouvernement Egyptien toute somme dont elle pourrait rester debi- trice apres remboursement de toutes les som- mes Iui revenant.

3. Defense a la Daira Sanieh de S.A. le Khedive d'avoir a verser au Gouvernement Egyptien toutes sommes dont elle serait encore detentrice apres remboursement de la Dette Generale de la Daira et apres remboursement des sommes pouvant etre dues pour frais avan- ces ou impots arrieres au Gouvernement Egyp- tien et apres acquittement de tous les engage- ments par elle pris.

Attendu, en effet, qu'aux termes de l'article 471 du Code de procedure la saisie arret ne peut etre pratiqee qu'en vertu d'un titre arthentique ou prive etablissant une creance liquide, et aux termes de l'article 473 qu'avec permission du juge a'il n'y a pas de titre ou si la creance qui resulte du titre n'est pasliquide.
Attendu que les hoirs de feu S.A. Ismail Pacha ont fait la defense dont s'agit sans titre et sans permission du juge et que des lors elle ne saurait produire aucun effet.

Mais attendu qu'il est a peine besoin d'ob- server que la saisie-revendication ne saurait etre pratiquee qu'en vertu d'un droir acquis, surtout s'agissant de revendiquer une somme indeterminee d'argent et non en vertu d'un- droir eventuel comme celui invoque par les hoirs de feu S.A. Ismail pacha.
Qu'en l'etat la competence du juge des refe- res ne saurait etre contestee, puisqu'il a'agit d'une mesur urgente a prendre.
P.C.M.,
Nous nous declarons competents ;
Donnons acte a la Daira Sanieh de S.A. le Khedive de son intervention.

Autorisons la Societe Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh a se liberer valablement entre les maiss du Gouvernement Egyptien de toutes les som- mes qu'elle peut lui devoit a quelque titre que ce soit, sans tenir compte de l'exploit pre- cite du 10 sout 1905, et s'il n'existe pas d'au- tre empechement legal de saisie.
Depens a la charge des heritiers de feu S.A. Ismail pachs.
Ordonnons l'execution de la presente ordon- nance sur la minute.

div.head: Mille Alma Thompson
div.p: Mile Alma Thompson, grade modiste parisienne, arrivee ici il y a quelques jours et descendue a l'un des principaux hotels de notre ville, est morte mardi matin presque subite- ment.

Plusieurs amia de la malade voyant qu'une operation etsit indispensable pour la sauver, avient sollicite de sa famille l'autorisation necessaire, qui avait ete accordee. Mais au dernier moment, l'agonaissante avait categorique- ment refuse de se lai ser operer.

Les racontars les plus extraordinaires ont circule ces jours ci a propos de ce deces inat- tandu. Les informations que nouns avons prises a la meilleure source nous permettent de de- clarer que ces racontrars ne reposent sur aucun fondement.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: Members are reminded that the 60 yards Juniors’ and 110 yards Seniors’ Championships will take place at the new Graving Dock, Gibbari, to-morrow at 4 p.m , after which there will a be polo match between H.H.S. Aida and the club, which will be followed by a tug of war.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: The race between the boats of the Alexan- dria Rowing Club and tbe Deutscher Sport Verein which took place yesterday afternoon resulted, after an exciting struggle, in a victory for the German boat by nearly a length. Had the A.R.C. boat been better coxed the finish might have been very close indeed. To day the final will be rowed off between the German boat and the Canottiere, and a good race is anticipated.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.
In His Britannic majesty's Consular Court at Alexandria
Notice.
John Thomas Burton deceased.

Pursuant to Act of Parliament 22 and 23 Vict. o 35, intituled "An Act to further amend the Law of Property and to relieve Trustees," NOTICE is hereby given that all creditors and persons having any claims or demands upon or against the estate of JOHN THOMAS BURTON late of Ramleh Alexandria deceased (who died on or about the 12th day of September 1905, and whose will was proposved by Lucy Helen Booth Burton of Ramleh aforesaid spinster and John Hubbalday Burton of Alexandria Coal Merchant one of the Executives and the Executor therein named on the 5th day of October 1905 in his Britannic Majesty's Consular Court at Alexandria) are hereby re- quired to send in particulars of their claims and demands to the undersigned, the Advocate of the said Executrix and Exeutor will proceed to distribute the assets of the deseased among the parties entitled thereto, having regard only to the claims of which the said Executrix and Executor shall then have notice, and that they will not be liable for the assets or any part thereof so distributed to any per- son of whose debt or claim they shall not then have had notice.
Dated this 13th day of October 1905. Frederick Levaux, 9, Rue, Debbane, Alexandria Solicitor of the Supreme Court in England. Avocat pres la Cour Mixite. 26554-2-1

div.head: Official Notice.
div.p: Proposal to change a ship's name. I, De Witt Gray, Secretary of the Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company , Limit- ed, of 7 1/2, Bishopagate Street Within, in the City of London, hereby give notice that in consequence of her name not being in con- formity with those of the other vessels owned by the Company, it is my intention to apply to the Board of Trade, under ssectrion 47 of the Merchant Shipping Act, 1894, in respect of the steamer Vassilefs Ghoerghios of Andros, Greece, of Gross Tonnage 1,630 tons, of Register Tonnage 1,018 tons, heretofore owned by the Ionian Steam Navigation Co., Messrs Destouni and Yauuoulatos, Managers, for permission to change her name to Kosseir, to be registered in the said new name at the Port of London, as owned by the Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company, Limited.
Any objections to the proposed change of name must be sent to the Assistant Secretary Marine Department, Board of Trade, within seven days from the appearance of this Adver- tisement.
Dated at London this 10th day of October 1905.
De Witt Gray, 26559-1 Secretary.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
